722047f-a.text:
Park Avenue, west side, from East 34th to 35th Street's, showing prominently the Community Church at the N. E. corner of the first point. At the right is the Church of the Covenant at a similar location at 35th Street. In the foreground is the former railroad tunnel that extends to 42nd Street. At the date of this photo it is being used for street-cars. On the left margin is a private dwelling occupying a portion
of the site of the future Hotel Vanderbilt.
Prior to 1890
Gift of Urbrock Collection

722044f.text:
Park Ave., east side, at East 34th Street. This view shows the Lexington Ave. Subway under construction, which will run under the former railroad tunnel which is used by street cars at this time. The 71st Regiment
Armory appears on the right.
October 4,.1900.
William B. Farsons Collection.

722037f-a.text:
Park Avenue at 34th Street. South Side. Before.

February 14, 1919

722038f-a.text:
Park Avenue north from 34th Street, showing the contrast of the
old and new in the transition era.
On the northwest corner of 34th Street stands the Community Church or Church of the Messiah (Unitarian), build in 1867. It will be demolished in 1931. Above it stands a new apartment house. On the east side in the same block, the 15 Park Avenue apartment house was built about 1923; and the small house on the S. E. corner of 35th Street is about to be demolished to make room for a similar 16-story apuartment hotel. On the N. E. corner of 35th Street the old Robb house has been occupied since 1923 by the Advertising Club, after having been a ooarding house for some years. The Women's City Ciub occupies the house on t he N. W. corner opposite. The next new apartment building on the east side is The Russell, the 9-story house erected in 1923 on the S. E. corner of 37th Street, the site of the old Judge Russell residence.
April 19cc5.
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

722048f-a.text:
Park Avenue, east side, from 35th to 34th Streets, showing 15 and 17 Park Avenue on the S.E. corner of 35th Street.
No. 15 is an apartment house; 17 is an apartment hotel. Both were designed, financed, and constructed by the Fred. F. French Company. The house on the corner is the old 1 Park Avenue, the residence of Mrs. Hobert Bacon, who at the time of this picture is contesting the use of this number with the new One Park Avenue Building, part of which is seen in the right background behind the tower of the Seventy-First Regiment Armory.

January 29, 1926.

Peyser & Patsig, Inc., Photographers
Gift of Fred. F. French Co.

722080f-a.text:
Park Avenue, south on west side, from 39th to 34th Streets, seen
from 40th Street.
The old residence on the S.W. corner of 39th Street will be demolished in September 1933. The 70 Park Avenue Hotel, shown on the N.W. corner of 38th Street, was built since 1925; and on the S.W. corner of 37th Street the houses are still standing that will give way in 1930 to the new Union League Clubhouse. The Vanderbilt Hotel, on the block from 34th to 33rd Streets,
is shown at the extreme left.
May 6, 1928.
P. L. Sperr, Photogapher.

722031f.text:
5 Park Avenue, formerly 1 Park Avenue, residence of Mrs. Robert Bacon, at the N.E. corner of 34th Street. When the new One Park Avenue office building between 32nd and 33rd Streets was opened in 1926, Mrs. Hacon sought in the courts to preserve that number for her house; and it was restored to her by the Appelate Court in November 1927, but finally lost to her in February 1928.
The old buildings surrounding this house have been demolished, and an L-shaped apartment house, the Green Park,
will be built around it.
1930
Ewing Galloway, Photographer

722041f-a.text:
Park Avenue, north from 34th Street, showing buildings along the east side.
The old Robb mansion on the N. E. corner of 35th Street houses the Advertising Club, who occupied it early in 1923. Behind it may be seen the skeleton of the Town House Apartments at 108 East 38th Street, under construction. In the right background rise the completed Chanin Building and the nearly completed Chrysler Building, on diagonally opposite corners of Lexington Avenue and 42nd Street. In the left background the New York Central Building, 230 Park Avenue at 40th Street, towers over the Grand Central Station.

Early 1930.
Ewing Galloway, Photographer.
Neg. #5044
Slide 256

712141f-a.text:
(1)
34th Street, north side, east from Park Avenue.
March 10, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

(2)
A portion of the same, at a later date, and showing a more restricted view of the block from Park Ave., to but not including Lexington Ave. The 20-story apartment house seen prominently, is the Green-Park Building, bearing Nos. 107-113 East 34th Street, on the site where formerly stood four 5-story houses, Nos. 107 to 113, seen in view 1. Shown also, is a general view northward of the surrounding area, from the 71st Regiment Armory, at the S.E. corner of Park Ave. and 34th Street, with the Chrysler, Chanin, and New York Central Buildings appearing in the background (from right to left).

February 27, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722034f-b.text:
Park Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 34th Street, showing the tower atop the 71st Regiment Armory at that location and viewed northwestward from No. 1 Park Ave. In the background, beyond same is the tall No. 10 East 40th Street Building, so nearly in line with No. 500 Pifth Ave. as to almost hide the latter. Note in the lower foreground the roofs of the Community Church and the Green residence (old No. 1 Park Ave.) on the left and right of the Armory tower respectively. The former has been replaced by a modern apartment house. This set consists of a negative and positive photostat of an original photograph
which was discoloring in the files.
January 15, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722034f-a.text:
Park Ave., at the S.E. corner of East 34th Street, showing the tower atop the 71st Regiment Armory at that location and viewed northwestward from No. 1 Park Ave. In the background, beyond same is the tall No. 10 East 40th Street Building, so nearly in line with No. 500 Pifth Ave. as to almost hide the latter. Note in the lower foreground the roofs of the Community Church and the Green residence (old No. 1 Park Ave.) on the left and right of the Armory tower respectively. The former has been replaced by a modern apartment house. This set consists of a negative and positive photostat of an original photograph
which was discoloring in the files.
January 15, 1931.
P. L. Sperr.

722036f-b.text:
Park Avenue, west side, south from East 34th Street, showing the Hotel Vanderbilt (erected 1911) and the office structure, No. 2 Park Avenue. Each of these occupy an entire block frontage, the the former, 34th to 33rd and the latter, 33rd to 32nd Streets. Fourth Avenue begins at the last mentioned street. Note the vague outline of the New York Life Iygsurance Company Building at the upper left and the partially dismantled Community Church in the lower right. The latter was replaced by the apartment-hotel No. 10
Park Avenue.
View 2 1s limited to the Vanderbilt Hotel elevation.
February 27, 1931
Views 1,2
P. L. Sperr

722039f-b.text:
(1)
Community Church, Park Avenue at N.W. corner of 34th Street,
showing the side entrance on Park Avenue.
This Unitanian church was built in 1867 and officially known as the Church of the Messiah. In 1931 it will be demolished
and give place to an apartment building.
March 10, 1929.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(2)
Park Avenue at N.W. corner of 34th Street, showing the Community
Church, demolition about to begin.
February 22, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
(3)
Park Avenue at N.W. corner of 34th Street, seen from 17 Park Avenue across the street, showing the Community Church after
demolition has been going on for a week.
February 27, 1931.
P. L. Sperr, Photographer.
